mil3.2.1:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo uppajjati, so eva so, udāhu añño”ti?
mil3.2.1:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is the one who arises the same or otherwise?”

mil3.2.1:2.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadā tvaṃ daharo taruṇo mando uttānaseyyako ahosi, soyeva tvaṃ etarahi mahanto”ti?
mil3.2.1:2.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when you were a child, young and tender and lying on your back, were you the same as you are now that you are grown?”

mil3.2.1:2.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, añño so daharo taruṇo mando uttānaseyyako ahosi, añño ahaṃ etarahi mahanto”ti.
mil3.2.1:2.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir. That child, young and tender and lying on his back was one thing, and I now grown am another.”

mil3.2.1:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ sante kho, mahārāja, mātātipi na bhavissati, pitātipi na bhavissati, ācariyotipi na bhavissati, sippavātipi na bhavissati, sīlavātipi na bhavissati, paññavātipi na bhavissati.
mil3.2.1:2.4.eng: “That being so, your majesty, there would be no notion of mother, nor of father, nor of teacher, nor of a craftsperson, nor of a virtuous person, nor of a wise person.

mil3.2.1:2.5.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, aññā eva kalalassa mātā, aññā abbudassa mātā, aññā pesiyā mātā, aññā ghanassa mātā, aññā khuddakassa mātā, aññā mahantassa mātā, añño sippaṃ sikkhati, añño sikkhito bhavati, añño pāpakammaṃ karoti, aññassa hatthapādā chijjantī”ti?
mil3.2.1:2.5.eng: Can it be, your majesty, that the mother of the embryo is different from the mother at the next foetal stage, which is different from the mother of following foetal stages, that the mother of a child is different from the mother of the grown person, that one who trains in a craft is different from the one who is trained, that the one who commits an evil deed is different from the one whose hands and feet are cut off?”

mil3.2.1:2.7.pli: Tvaṃ pana, bhante, evaṃ vutte, kiṃ vadeyyāsī”ti?
mil3.2.1:2.7.eng: And what would you say if somebody said this to be so?”

mil3.2.1:2.9.pli: “ahaññeva kho, mahārāja, daharo ahosiṃ taruṇo mando uttānaseyyako, ahaññeva etarahi mahanto, imameva kāyaṃ nissāya sabbe te ekasaṅgahitā”ti.
mil3.2.1:2.9.eng: “It was just I, your majesty, who was a child, young and tender and lying on my back, and now it is just I who has grown, and all these states are held together dependent on just this body.”

mil3.2.1:3.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso padīpaṃ padīpeyya, kiṃ so sabbarattiṃ padīpeyyā”ti?
mil3.2.1:3.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person might light a lamp, might it stay lit all night?”

mil3.2.1:3.3.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, it might stay lit all night.”

mil3.2.1:3.4.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, yā purime yāme acci, sā majjhime yāme accī”ti?
mil3.2.1:3.4.eng: “Is it so, your majesty, that the flame in the first watch of the night is the same as that in the middle watch?”

mil3.2.1:3.6.pli: “Yā majjhime yāme acci, sā pacchime yāme accī”ti?
mil3.2.1:3.6.eng: “Is the flame in the middle watch of the night the same as that in the last watch?”

mil3.2.1:3.8.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, añño so ahosi purime yāme padīpo, añño majjhime yāme padīpo, añño pacchime yāme padīpo”ti?
mil3.2.1:3.8.eng: “Is it then so, your majesty, that the lamp in the first watch of the night is different from that in the middle watch, which is different from that in the last watch?”

mil3.2.1:3.9.pli: “Na hi, bhante, taṃyeva nissāya sabbarattiṃ padīpito”ti.
mil3.2.1:3.9.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir. It was burning all through the night dependent on just itself.”

mil3.2.1:3.10.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, dhammasantati sandahati, añño uppajjati, añño nirujjhati, apubbaṃ acarimaṃ viya sandahati, tena na ca so, na ca añño, purimaviññāṇe pacchimaviññāṇaṃ saṅgahaṃ gacchatī”ti.
mil3.2.1:3.10.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, a continuity of states runs on; as one arises, another ceases. It runs on like there was no before and no after. Consequently, it is neither the same nor the other and the last consciousness is comprised of the first consciousness.”

mil3.2.1:4.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, khīraṃ duyhamānaṃ kālantarena dadhi parivatteyya, dadhito navanītaṃ, navanītato ghataṃ parivatteyya, yo nu kho, mahārāja, evaṃ vadeyya ‘yaṃyeva khīraṃ taṃyeva dadhi, yaṃyeva dadhi taṃyeva navanītaṃ, yaṃyeva navanītaṃ taṃyeva ghatan’ti, sammā nu kho so, mahārāja, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
mil3.2.1:4.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, milk some time after being milked from a cow would turn to curds, and from curds into butter, and from butter to ghee, would someone who might say, ‘That milk is those curds, those curds is that butter, that butter is that ghee,’ be speaking rightly?”

mil3.2.1:4.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, they come into being because of it.”

mil3.2.1:4.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, dhammasantati sandahati, añño uppajjati, añño nirujjhati, apubbaṃ acarimaṃ viya sandahati, tena na ca so, na ca añño, purimaviññāṇe pacchimaviññāṇaṃ saṅgahaṃ gacchatī”ti.
mil3.2.1:4.4.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, a continuity of states runs on; as one arises, another ceases. It runs on like there was no before and no after. Consequently, it is neither the same nor the other and the last consciousness is comprised of the first consciousness.”

mil3.2.2:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo na paṭisandahati, jānāti so ‘na paṭisandahissāmī’”ti?
mil3.2.2:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, does someone who does not reconnect know ‘I will not reconnect’?”

mil3.2.2:1.3.pli: “Āma, mahārāja, yo na paṭisandahati, jānāti so ‘na paṭisandahissāmī’”ti.
mil3.2.2:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, someone who does not reconnect knows ‘I will not reconnect’.”

mil3.2.2:1.5.pli: “Yo hetu yo paccayo, mahārāja, paṭisandahanāya, tassa hetussa tassa paccayassa uparamā jānāti so ‘na paṭisandahissāmī’”ti.
mil3.2.2:1.5.eng: “From the cessation, your majesty, of the cause and condition for reconnecting one knows ‘I will not reconnect’.”

mil3.2.2:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kassako gahapatiko kasitvā ca vapitvā ca dhaññāgāraṃ paripūreyya.
mil3.2.2:2.2.eng: “Just like, your majesty, a householder farmer, having ploughed and sown might fill his grain house.

mil3.2.2:2.3.pli: So aparena samayena neva kasseyya na vappeyya, yathāsambhatañca dhaññaṃ paribhuñjeyya vā visajjeyya vā yathā paccayaṃ vā kareyya, jāneyya so, mahārāja, kassako gahapatiko ‘na me dhaññāgāraṃ paripūressatī’”ti?
mil3.2.2:2.3.eng: But then, after some time, he would not plough and sow, and would use up the grain he had stored, or dispose of it, or deal with it according to conditions, would that householder farmer know, your majesty, ‘I will not fill my grain house’?”

mil3.2.2:2.6.pli: “Yo hetu yo paccayo dhaññāgārassa paripūraṇāya, tassa hetussa tassa paccayassa uparamā jānāti ‘na me dhaññāgāraṃ paripūressatī’”ti.
mil3.2.2:2.6.eng: “From the cessation of that cause and condition for filling the grain house one knows ‘I will not fill my grain house’.”

mil3.2.2:2.7.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yo hetu yo paccayo paṭisandahanāya, tassa hetussa tassa paccayassa uparamā jānāti so ‘na paṭisandahissāmī’”ti.
mil3.2.2:2.7.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, from the cessation of the cause and condition for reconnecting one knows ‘I will not reconnect’.”

mil3.2.3:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yassa ñāṇaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa paññā uppannā”ti?
mil3.2.3:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, for one in whom knowledge has arisen, would wisdom also have arisen?”

mil3.2.3:1.3.pli: “Āma, mahārāja, yassa ñāṇaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa paññā uppannā”ti.
mil3.2.3:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, for one in whom knowledge has arisen, wisdom also has arisen.”

mil3.2.3:1.4.eng: “What, venerable sir, is knowledge the same as wisdom?”

mil3.2.3:1.5.eng: “Yes, your majesty, knowledge is the same as wisdom.”

mil3.2.3:1.6.pli: “Yassa pana, bhante, taññeva ñāṇaṃ sāyeva paññā uppannā, kiṃ sammuyheyya so, udāhu na sammuyheyyā”ti?
mil3.2.3:1.6.eng: “Then, venerable sir, for one in whom knowledge has arisen which is the same as wisdom, would he be confused or would he not be confused?”

mil3.2.3:1.7.eng: “He would be confused in some instances, your majesty, and would not be confused in other instances.”

mil3.2.3:1.8.eng: “When, venerable sir, would he be confused?”

mil3.2.3:1.9.pli: “Aññātapubbesu vā, mahārāja, sippaṭṭhānesu, agatapubbāya vā disāya, assutapubbāya vā nāmapaññattiyā sammuyheyyā”ti.
mil3.2.3:1.9.eng: “He would be confused, your majesty, concerning those aspects of a craft that he did not know before, or those directions in which he has not gone before, or those names and designations he has not heard before.”

mil3.2.3:1.10.eng: “When, venerable sir, would he not be confused?”

mil3.2.3:1.11.pli: “Yaṃ kho pana, mahārāja, tāya paññāya kataṃ ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā, tahiṃ na sammuyheyyā”ti.
mil3.2.3:1.11.eng: “He would not be confused, your majesty, concerning that which he has discerned by wisdom, that is, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self.”

mil3.2.3:1.12.eng: “Then where, venerable sir, does his confusion go?”

mil3.2.3:1.13.pli: “Moho kho, mahārāja, ñāṇe uppannamatte tattheva nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:1.13.eng: “Confusion ceases, your majesty, at that very moment when knowledge arises.”

mil3.2.3:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso andhakāragehe padīpaṃ āropeyya, tato andhakāro nirujjheyya, āloko pātubhaveyya;
mil3.2.3:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person might bring in a lamp to a dark house, then the darkness ceases, and light appears.

mil3.2.3:2.3.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, ñāṇe uppannamatte moho tattheva nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:2.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, at the moment when knowledge arises, right there confusion ceases.”

mil3.2.3:3.1.eng: “Then where, venerable sir, does wisdom go?”

mil3.2.3:3.2.pli: “Paññāpi kho, mahārāja, sakiccayaṃ katvā tattheva nirujjhati, yaṃ pana tāya paññāya kataṃ ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā, taṃ na nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:3.2.eng: “Wisdom, your majesty, ceases right there having done its task, but that understood by wisdom, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self do not cease.”

mil3.2.3:4.1.pli: “Bhante nāgasena, yaṃ panetaṃ brūsi ‘paññā sakiccayaṃ katvā tattheva nirujjhati, yaṃ pana tāya paññāya kataṃ “aniccan”ti vā “dukkhan”ti vā “anattā”ti vā, taṃ na nirujjhatī’ti, tassa opammaṃ karohī”ti.
mil3.2.3:4.1.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, what you have just said, ‘Wisdom ceases right there having done its task, but that understood by wisdom, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self do not cease,’ please make an analogy for that.”

mil3.2.3:4.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, yo koci puriso rattiṃ lekhaṃ pesetukāmo lekhakaṃ pakkosāpetvā padīpaṃ āropetvā lekhaṃ likhāpeyya, likhite pana lekhe padīpaṃ vijjhāpeyya, vijjhāpitepi padīpe lekhaṃ na vinasseyya.
mil3.2.3:4.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person, wishing to send a letter at night, would summon a scribe and light a lamp, and have the letter written. Then, when the letter is written, he would extinguish the lamp. And when the lamp is extinguished the letter would not be destroyed.

mil3.2.3:4.3.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, paññā sakiccayaṃ katvā tattheva nirujjhati, yaṃ pana tāya paññāya kataṃ ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā, taṃ na nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:4.3.eng: In the same way, your majesty, wisdom ceases right there having done its task, but that understood by wisdom, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self do not cease.”

mil3.2.3:5.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, puratthimesu janapadesu manussā anugharaṃ pañca pañca udakaghaṭakāni ṭhapenti ālimpanaṃ vijjhāpetuṃ, ghare paditte tāni pañca udakaghaṭakāni gharassūpari khipanti, tato aggi vijjhāyati, kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, tesaṃ manussānaṃ evaṃ hoti ‘puna tehi ghaṭehi ghaṭakiccaṃ karissāmā’”ti?
mil3.2.3:5.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, people in the eastern districts might set up five water pots in each house so as to extinguish any burning, and when a house is on fire, they would throw these five pots of water on top of the house, then the fire would be extinguished. Would it occur to these people, your majesty, ‘We must make use of these pots again’?”

mil3.2.3:5.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, alaṃ tehi ghaṭehi, kiṃ tehi ghaṭehī”ti?
mil3.2.3:5.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, those pots have done their job, what further need would there be for them?”

mil3.2.3:5.4.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, pañca udakaghaṭakāni, evaṃ pañcindriyāni daṭṭhabbāni saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyaṃ.
mil3.2.3:5.4.eng: “As, your majesty, are the five pots of water, so the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom are to be seen.

mil3.2.3:5.5.pli: Yathā te manussā, evaṃ yogāvacaro daṭṭhabbo.
mil3.2.3:5.5.eng: As those people, so the spiritual practitioner is to be seen.

mil3.2.3:5.6.eng: As the fire, so the defilements are to be seen.

mil3.2.3:5.7.pli: Yathā pañcahi udakaghaṭakehi aggi vijjhāpīyati, evaṃ pañcindriyehi kilesā vijjhāpiyanti, vijjhāpitāpi kilesā na puna sambhavanti.
mil3.2.3:5.7.eng: As the fire is extinguished by the five pots of water, so the defilements are extinguished by the five faculties, and those extinguished defilements do not arise again.

mil3.2.3:5.8.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, paññā sakiccayaṃ katvā tattheva nirujjhati, yaṃ pana tāya paññāya kataṃ ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā, taṃ na nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:5.8.eng: In the same way, your majesty, wisdom ceases right there having done its task, but that understood by wisdom, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self do not cease.”

mil3.2.3:6.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, vejjo pañcamūlabhesajjāni gahetvā gilānakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tāni pañcamūlabhesajjāni pisitvā gilānakaṃ pāyeyya, tehi ca dosā niddhameyyuṃ, kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, tassa vejjassa evaṃ hoti ‘puna tehi pañcamūlabhesajjehi bhesajjakiccaṃ karissāmī’”ti?
mil3.2.3:6.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a doctor, having taken the five root medicines and approached a sick person, might crush the five root medicines and get the sick person to drink them, and the sickness would disappear. Would it occur to that doctor, your majesty, ‘I will make use of the five root medicines again’?”

mil3.2.3:6.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, alaṃ tehi pañcamūlabhesajjehi, kiṃ tehi pañcamūlabhesajjehī”ti?
mil3.2.3:6.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, those five root medicines have done their job, what further need would there be for them?”

mil3.2.3:6.4.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, pañcamūlabhesajjāni, evaṃ pañcindriyāni daṭṭhabbāni saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyaṃ, yathā vejjo, evaṃ yogāvacaro daṭṭhabbo.
mil3.2.3:6.4.eng: “As, your majesty, are the five root medicines, so the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom are to be seen. As the doctor, so the spiritual practitioner is to be seen.

mil3.2.3:6.5.eng: As the disease, so the defilements are to be seen.

mil3.2.3:6.6.pli: Yathā byādhito puriso, evaṃ puthujjano daṭṭhabbo.
mil3.2.3:6.6.eng: As the sick person, so the common person is to be seen.

mil3.2.3:6.7.pli: Yathā pañcamūlabhesajjehi gilānassa dosā niddhantā, dose niddhante gilāno arogo hoti, evaṃ pañcindriyehi kilesā niddhamīyanti, niddhamitā ca kilesā na puna sambhavanti.
mil3.2.3:6.7.eng: As the disease of the sick person is expelled by the five root medicines such that when the disease is expelled the sick person becomes well, so the defilements are expelled by the five faculties, and those expelled defilements do not arise again.

mil3.2.3:6.8.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, paññā sakiccayaṃ katvā tattheva nirujjhati, yaṃ pana tāya paññāya kataṃ ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā, taṃ na nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:6.8.eng: In the same way, your majesty, wisdom ceases right there having done its task, but that understood by wisdom, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self do not cease.”

mil3.2.3:7.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, saṅgāmāvacaro yodho pañca kaṇḍāni gahetvā saṅgāmaṃ otareyya parasenaṃ vijetuṃ, so saṅgāmagato tāni pañca kaṇḍāni khipeyya, tehi ca parasenā bhijjeyya, kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, tassa saṅgāmāvacarassa yodhassa evaṃ hoti ‘puna tehi kaṇḍehi kaṇḍakiccaṃ karissāmī’”ti?
mil3.2.3:7.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, a warrior, skilled in battle, having taken five arrows and entered into battle in order to defeat an opposing army, and gone into battle he might let fly those five arrows, and the opposing army is destroyed by them. Would it occur to that warrior, skilled in battle, your majesty, ‘I will make use of these five arrows again’?”

mil3.2.3:7.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, alaṃ tehi kaṇḍehi, kiṃ tehi kaṇḍehī”ti?
mil3.2.3:7.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, those five arrows have done their job, what further need would there be for them?”

mil3.2.3:7.4.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, pañca kaṇḍāni, evaṃ pañcindriyāni daṭṭhabbāni saddhindriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ satindriyaṃ samādhindriyaṃ paññindriyaṃ.
mil3.2.3:7.4.eng: “As, your majesty, are the five arrows, so the five faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom are to be seen.

mil3.2.3:7.5.pli: Yathā, mahārāja, saṅgāmāvacaro yodho, evaṃ yogāvacaro daṭṭhabbo.
mil3.2.3:7.5.eng: As the warrior, skilled in battle, so the spiritual practitioner is to be seen.

mil3.2.3:7.6.eng: As the opposing army, so the defilements are to be seen.

mil3.2.3:7.7.pli: Yathā pañcahi kaṇḍehi parasenā bhijjati, evaṃ pañcindriyehi kilesā bhijjanti, bhaggā ca kilesā na puna sambhavanti.
mil3.2.3:7.7.eng: As the opposing army is destroyed by the five arrows, so the defilements are destroyed by the five faculties, and those destroyed defilements do not arise again.

mil3.2.3:7.8.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, paññā sakiccayaṃ katvā tattheva nirujjhati, yaṃ pana tāya paññāya kataṃ ‘aniccan’ti vā ‘dukkhan’ti vā ‘anattā’ti vā, taṃ na nirujjhatī”ti.
mil3.2.3:7.8.eng: In the same way, your majesty, wisdom ceases right there having done its task, but that understood by wisdom, the notions of impermanent, suffering, and not self do not cease.”

mil3.2.4:0.3.eng: 4. Question on the Feelings of an Individual Reconnecting

mil3.2.4:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo na paṭisandahati, vedeti so kiñci dukkhaṃ vedanan”ti?
mil3.2.4:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, does one who does not reconnect feel a painful feeling?”

mil3.2.4:1.4.eng: “He feels some, and he does not feel others.”

mil3.2.4:1.5.eng: “Which does he feel, and which does he not feel?”

mil3.2.4:1.6.pli: “Kāyikaṃ, mahārāja, vedanaṃ vedeti, cetasikaṃ vedanaṃ na vedetī”ti.
mil3.2.4:1.6.eng: “He feels bodily feelings, your majesty, and he does not feel mental feelings.”

mil3.2.4:1.7.pli: “Kathaṃ, bhante, kāyikaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, kathaṃ cetasikaṃ vedanaṃ na vedetī”ti?
mil3.2.4:1.7.eng: “How, venerable sir, does he feel bodily feelings, and how does he not feel mental feelings?”

mil3.2.4:1.8.pli: “Yo hetu yo paccayo kāyikāya dukkhavedanāya uppattiyā, tassa hetussa tassa paccayassa anuparamā kāyikaṃ dukkhavedanaṃ vedeti, yo hetu yo paccayo cetasikāya dukkhavedanāya uppattiyā, tassa hetussa tassa paccayassa uparamā cetasikaṃ dukkhavedanaṃ na vedeti.
mil3.2.4:1.8.eng: “There is no ceasing of that cause and condition for the arising of a painful bodily feeling, and thus he feels a painful bodily feeling. There is ceasing of that cause and condition for the arising of a painful mental feeling, and thus he does not feel a painful mental feeling.

mil3.2.4:1.9.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.2.4:1.10.pli: ‘so ekaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti kāyikaṃ na cetasikan’”ti.
mil3.2.4:1.10.eng: ‘He only feels one feeling, the bodily one, not the mental.’”

mil3.2.4:2.1.pli: “Bhante nāgasena, yo dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, kasmā so na parinibbāyatī”ti?
mil3.2.4:2.1.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, why does one who feels a painful feeling not experience final nibbāna?”

mil3.2.4:2.2.pli: “Natthi, mahārāja, arahato anunayo vā paṭigho vā, na ca arahanto apakkaṃ pātenti paripākaṃ āgamenti paṇḍitā.
mil3.2.4:2.2.eng: “For an arahant, your majesty, there is no delight nor repugnance, and arahants do not destroy what is unripe. The wise ones wait for full maturing.

mil3.2.4:2.3.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the elder Sāriputta, the general of the Dhamma:

mil3.2.4:3.2.eng: nor do I delight in living.

mil3.2.4:3.3.eng: But I wait for the right time,

mil3.2.4:3.4.eng: as a servant waits for his wages.

mil3.2.4:4.2.eng: nor do I delight in living.

mil3.2.4:4.3.eng: But I wait for the right time,

mil3.2.4:6.1.eng: Question on the Feelings of an Individual Reconnecting fourth

mil3.2.5:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, sukhā vedanā kusalā vā akusalā vā abyākatā vā”ti?
mil3.2.5:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is pleasant feeling wholesome or unwholesome or indeterminate?”

mil3.2.5:1.3.pli: “Siyā, mahārāja, kusalā, siyā akusalā, siyā abyākatā”ti.
mil3.2.5:1.3.eng: “It could be wholesome, your majesty, or it could be unwholesome, or it could be indeterminate.”

mil3.2.5:1.4.pli: “Yadi, bhante, kusalā na dukkhā, yadi dukkhā na kusalā, kusalaṃ dukkhanti nuppajjatī”ti.
mil3.2.5:1.4.eng: “If, venerable sir, wholesome feelings are not painful, and if painful feelings are not wholesome, then there does not arise a wholesome feeling which is painful.”

mil3.2.5:1.5.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, idha purisassa hatthe tattaṃ ayoguḷaṃ nikkhipeyya, dutiye hatthe sītaṃ himapiṇḍaṃ nikkhipeyya, kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, ubhopi te daheyyun”ti?
mil3.2.5:1.5.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, if one might place a hot iron ball in a man’s hand and place a snowball in his other hand, would both hurt him?”

mil3.2.5:1.6.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, they would both hurt him.”

mil3.2.5:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho te, mahārāja, ubhopi uṇhā”ti?
mil3.2.5:1.7.eng: “Well, your majesty, are they both hot?”

mil3.2.5:1.9.eng: “What then, your majesty, are they both cold?”

mil3.2.5:1.11.pli: “Ājānāhi niggahaṃ yadi tattaṃ dahati, na ca te ubhopi uṇhā, tena nuppajjati.
mil3.2.5:1.11.eng: “Know your own refutation. If something hot hurts, and they are not both hot, it is not because of that the suffering arises.

mil3.2.5:1.12.pli: Yadi sītalaṃ dahati, na ca te ubhopi sītalā, tena nuppajjati.
mil3.2.5:1.12.eng: And, if something cold hurts, and they are not both cold, it is not because of that the suffering arises.

mil3.2.5:1.13.pli: Kissa pana te, mahārāja, ubhopi dahanti, na ca te ubhopi uṇhā, na ca te ubhopi sītalā?
mil3.2.5:1.13.eng: So, how is it, your majesty, that both hurt, and they are not both hot, and they are not both cold?

mil3.2.5:1.14.pli: Ekaṃ uṇhaṃ, ekaṃ sītalaṃ, ubhopi te dahanti, tena nuppajjatī”ti.
mil3.2.5:1.14.eng: And, how is it that with one hot and the other cold, they both hurt, and it is not because of that the suffering arises?”

mil3.2.5:1.15.pli: “Nāhaṃ paṭibalo tayā vādinā saddhiṃ sallapituṃ, sādhu atthaṃ jappehī”ti.
mil3.2.5:1.15.eng: “I am not competent to converse with you, a debater of the doctrine. It would be good, venerable sir, if you told me the meaning.”

mil3.2.5:1.16.pli: Tato thero abhidhammasaṃyuttāya kathāya rājānaṃ milindaṃ saññāpesi—
mil3.2.5:1.16.eng: Then the elder instructed King Milinda with a talk connected with Abhidhamma.

mil3.2.5:2.1.pli: “Chayimāni, mahārāja, gehanissitāni somanassāni, cha nekkhammanissitāni somanassāni, cha gehanissitāni domanassāni, cha nekkhammanissitāni domanassāni, cha gehanissitā upekkhā, cha nekkhammanissitā upekkhāti, imāni cha chakkāni, atītāpi chattiṃsavidhā vedanā, anāgatāpi chattiṃsavidhā vedanā, paccuppannāpi chattiṃsavidhā vedanā, tadekajjhaṃ abhisaññūhitvā abhisampiṇḍetvā aṭṭhasataṃ vedanā hontī”ti.
mil3.2.5:2.1.eng: “There are, your majesty, these six joys dependent on the householder life, these six joys dependent on renunciation, these six sorrows dependent on the householder life, these six sorrows dependent on renunciation, these six neutral feelings dependent on the householder life, these six neutral feelings dependent on renunciation. Thus, there are these six sets of six. There are then thirty-six types of feeling in the past, thirty-six types of feeling in the future, and thirty-six types of feeling in the present. So, assembling them and bringing them all together, there are one hundred and eight types of feeling.”

mil3.2.6:0.3.eng: 6. Question on the Identity or Difference of Name-and-Form

mil3.2.6:1.6.pli: “Na kho, mahārāja, imaṃyeva nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandahati, iminā pana, mahārāja, nāmarūpena kammaṃ karoti sobhanaṃ vā pāpakaṃ vā, tena kammena aññaṃ nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandahatī”ti.
mil3.2.6:1.6.eng: “This very name-and-form, your majesty, does not reconnect. With this name-and-form one performs a lovely or an evil action, and by this action another name-and-form reconnects.”

mil3.2.6:1.7.pli: “Yadi, bhante, na imaṃ yeva nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandahati, nanu so mutto bhavissati pāpakehi kammehī”ti?
mil3.2.6:1.7.eng: “If, venerable sir, this very name-and-form does not reconnect, is it not then that it would be freed from evil actions?”

mil3.2.6:1.9.pli: “yadi na paṭisandaheyya, mutto bhaveyya pāpakehi kammehi.
mil3.2.6:1.9.eng: “If it would not reconnect, then it would be freed from evil actions.

mil3.2.6:1.10.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahārāja, paṭisandahati, tasmā na mutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.2.6:1.10.eng: But because, your majesty, it does reconnect, it therefore is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.2.6:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso aññatarassa purisassa ambaṃ avahareyya, tamenaṃ ambasāmiko gahetvā rañño dasseyya ‘iminā, deva, purisena mayhaṃ ambā avahaṭā’ti, so evaṃ vadeyya ‘nāhaṃ, deva, imassa ambe avaharāmi, aññe te ambā, ye iminā ropitā, aññe te ambā, ye mayā avahaṭā, nāhaṃ daṇḍappatto’ti.
mil3.2.6:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person or other might steal another person’s mangos, and the mango owner might grab that person and point him out to the king, saying ‘My mangos have been stolen by this man.’ And he might say ‘Lord, I did not steal this person’s mangos. Those mangos I took are not the same as those that this person planted; I do not deserve punishment.’

mil3.2.6:2.3.pli: Kiṃ nu kho so, mahārāja, puriso daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti?
mil3.2.6:2.3.eng: Would that man, your majesty, deserve punishment?”

mil3.2.6:2.4.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, he would deserve punishment.”

mil3.2.6:2.6.pli: “Kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya, purimaṃ, bhante, ambaṃ appaccakkhāya pacchimena ambena so puriso daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti.
mil3.2.6:2.6.eng: “Whatever he might say, venerable sir, while not disavowing the earlier mangos, he would be deserving of punishment due to the later mangos.”

mil3.2.6:2.7.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, iminā nāmarūpena kammaṃ karoti sobhanaṃ vā pāpakaṃ vā, tena kammena aññaṃ nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandahati, tasmā na mutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.2.6:2.7.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, with this name-and-form one performs a lovely or an evil action, and by this action another name-and-form reconnects. Therefore, one is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.2.6:3.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso aññatarassa purisassa sāliṃ avahareyya …pe…
mil3.2.6:3.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person or other might steal another person’s rice, …

mil3.2.6:3.4.pli: yathā, mahārāja, koci puriso hemantakāle aggiṃ jāletvā visibbetvā avijjhāpetvā pakkameyya, atha kho so aggi aññatarassa purisassa khettaṃ ḍaheyya, tamenaṃ khettasāmiko gahetvā rañño dasseyya ‘iminā, deva, purisena mayhaṃ khettaṃ daḍḍhan’ti.
mil3.2.6:3.4.eng: Just as, your majesty, some person or other might light a fire during the wintertime, and warm himself, and might leave without having extinguished it, and that fire might burn another person’s field. And the owner of the field might grab that person and point him out to the king, saying ‘My field has been burned by this man.’

mil3.2.6:3.5.pli: So evaṃ vadeyya ‘nāhaṃ, deva, imassa khettaṃ jhāpemi, añño so aggi, yo mayā avijjhāpito, añño so aggi, yenimassa khettaṃ daḍḍhaṃ, nāhaṃ daṇḍappatto’ti.
mil3.2.6:3.5.eng: And he might say ‘Lord, I did not set fire to this person’s field. The fire I did not extinguish was not the same as the fire that burned this person’s field; I do not deserve punishment.’

mil3.2.6:3.6.pli: Kiṃ nu kho so, mahārāja, puriso daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti?
mil3.2.6:3.6.eng: Would that man, your majesty, deserve punishment?”

mil3.2.6:3.7.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, he would deserve punishment.”

mil3.2.6:3.9.pli: “Kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya, purimaṃ, bhante, aggiṃ appaccakkhāya pacchimena agginā so puriso daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti.
mil3.2.6:3.9.eng: “Whatever he might say, venerable sir, while not disavowing the earlier fire, he would be deserving of punishment by means of the later fire.”

mil3.2.6:3.10.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, iminā nāmarūpena kammaṃ karoti sobhanaṃ vā pāpakaṃ vā, tena kammena aññaṃ nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandahati, tasmā na mutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.2.6:3.10.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, with this name-and-form one performs a lovely or an evil action, and by this action another name-and-form reconnects. Therefore, one is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.2.6:4.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso padīpaṃ ādāya pāsādaṃ abhirūhitvā bhuñjeyya, padīpo jhāyamāno tiṇaṃ jhāpeyya, tiṇaṃ jhāyamānaṃ gharaṃ jhāpeyya, gharaṃ jhāyamānaṃ gāmaṃ jhāpeyya, gāmajano taṃ purisaṃ gahetvā evaṃ vadeyya ‘kissa tvaṃ, bho purisa, gāmaṃ jhāpesī’ti, so evaṃ vadeyya ‘nāhaṃ, bho, gāmaṃ jhāpemi, añño so padīpaggi, yassāhaṃ ālokena bhuñjiṃ, añño so aggi, yena gāmo jhāpito’ti, te vivadamānā tava santike āgaccheyyuṃ, kassa tvaṃ, mahārāja, aṭṭaṃ dhāreyyāsī”ti?
mil3.2.6:4.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person or other, having taken a lamp and ascended to the top of a mansion, might use it, and the burning lamp might set fire to the roof thatch, and the burning thatch might set fire to the house, and the burning house might set fire to the village, and the villagers, having seized that man, might say, ‘Why, sir, did you set fire to the village?’ And he might say ‘I did not, friend, set fire to the village. The fire in the lamp whose light I enjoyed was not the same as the fire that burned the village.’ And if they were to come before you while arguing, whose side of the argument, your majesty, would you support?”

mil3.2.6:4.5.pli: “Kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya, api ca tato eva so aggi nibbatto”ti.
mil3.2.6:4.5.eng: “Since, whatever he might say, this fire was produced just from that one.”

mil3.2.6:4.6.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kiñcāpi aññaṃ māraṇantikaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, aññaṃ paṭisandhismiṃ nāmarūpaṃ, api ca tatoyeva taṃ nibbattaṃ, tasmā na mutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.2.6:4.6.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, whatever name-and form that has death as its end, another name-and-form is in reconnection, and it was produced just from that one. Therefore, one is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.2.6:5.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso dahariṃ dārikaṃ vāretvā suṅkaṃ datvā pakkameyya.
mil3.2.6:5.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person or other, having contracted for a young girl in marriage and having paid the bride price, might leave.

mil3.2.6:5.3.pli: Sā aparena samayena mahatī assa vayappattā, tato añño puriso suṅkaṃ datvā vivāhaṃ kareyya, itaro āgantvā evaṃ vadeyya ‘kissa pana me tvaṃ, ambho purisa, bhariyaṃ nesī’ti?
mil3.2.6:5.3.eng: Then, after some time, she would reach full marriageable age, then another man, having paid the bride price would lead her away in marriage. The former man would come and say, ‘Why, sir, have you led away my wife?’

mil3.2.6:5.4.pli: So evaṃ vadeyya ‘nāhaṃ tava bhariyaṃ nemi, aññā sā dārikā daharī taruṇī, yā tayā vāritā ca dinnasuṅkā ca, aññāyaṃ dārikā mahatī vayappattā mayā vāritā ca dinnasuṅkā cā’ti, te vivadamānā tava santike āgaccheyyuṃ.
mil3.2.6:5.4.eng: And he might say ‘I have not led away your wife. The young girl for whom you have contracted and paid the bride price is not the same as the young woman who has attained marriageable age and been contracted for and paid for by me.’ And if they were to come before you while arguing,

mil3.2.6:5.5.eng: whose side of the argument, your majesty, would you support?”

mil3.2.6:5.6.eng: “That of the former man, venerable sir.”

mil3.2.6:5.8.pli: “Kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya, api ca tatoyeva sā mahatī nibbattā”ti.
mil3.2.6:5.8.eng: “Since, whatever he might say, this grown woman was produced just from that one.”

mil3.2.6:5.9.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kiñcāpi aññaṃ māraṇantikaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, aññaṃ paṭisandhismiṃ nāmarūpaṃ, api ca tatoyeva taṃ nibbattaṃ, tasmā naparimutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.2.6:5.9.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, whatever name-and form that has death as its end, another name-and-form is in reconnection, and it was produced just from that one. Therefore, one is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.2.6:6.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso gopālakassa hatthato khīraghaṭaṃ kiṇitvā tasseva hatthe nikkhipitvā pakkameyya ‘sve gahetvā gamissāmī’ti, taṃ aparajju dadhi sampajjeyya.
mil3.2.6:6.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person or other, having bought a pot of milk from the hand of a cowherd, might put it in his care and leave, saying, ‘I will come back for it tomorrow,’ and that milk would become curds.

mil3.2.6:6.3.pli: So āgantvā evaṃ vadeyya ‘dehi me khīraghaṭan’ti.
mil3.2.6:6.3.eng: Then, he might come back and say ‘Give me my pot of milk.’

mil3.2.6:6.4.eng: And the cowherd would show him the curds.

mil3.2.6:6.5.pli: Itaro evaṃ vadeyya ‘nāhaṃ tava hatthato dadhiṃ kiṇāmi, dehi me khīraghaṭan’ti.
mil3.2.6:6.5.eng: The other would then say, ‘I did not buy curds from you, give me my pot of milk.’

mil3.2.6:6.6.pli: So evaṃ vadeyya ‘ajānato te khīraṃ dadhibhūtan’ti te vivadamānā tava santike āgaccheyyuṃ, kassa tvaṃ, mahārāja, aṭṭaṃ dhāreyyāsī”ti?
mil3.2.6:6.6.eng: Then, that one would say, ‘Without you knowing it, the milk has become curds.’ And if they were to come before you while arguing, whose side of the argument, your majesty, would you support?”

mil3.2.6:6.9.pli: “Kiñcāpi so evaṃ vadeyya, api ca tato yeva taṃ nibbattan”ti.
mil3.2.6:6.9.eng: “Since, whatever he might say, this one was produced just from that one.”

mil3.2.6:6.10.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kiñcāpi aññaṃ māraṇantikaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, aññaṃ paṭisandhismiṃ nāmarūpaṃ, api ca tato yeva taṃ nibbattaṃ, tasmā na parimutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.2.6:6.10.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, whatever name-and form that has death as its end, another name-and-form is in reconnection, and it was produced just from that one. Therefore, one is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.2.6:8.1.eng: Question on the Identity or Difference of Name-and-Form sixth
